notesStmt.note: 2 leaves foliated 1-2, upper left and lower right verso.
Dated in the 19th century based on the watermark, which refers to the 19th century without giving the decade.
Manuscript on machine-made paper with a watermark of an 18 that is cut off, most likely referring to the 1800s, as is typical on such stocks of paper.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Manuscript is used for contemplation, study, recitation, and prayer, and some of its mantras and various other verses are possibly drawn from the Atharvaveda, although the text seems also to have been influenced by medieval Tantric traditions with speculations about the nature and status of divine feminine power, the Śakti. The work is of a quasi-philosophical nature and may be identified with some form of Śaivism although alluding to and styling itself after a late-Vedic upaniṣad.
